MARVIS

marvis.viz

Visualization framework for multi-modal data analysis.

Base Classes

Base classes for the MARVIS visualization system.

This module provides abstract base classes and data structures for implementing modular visualization components that can be composed together for enhanced reasoning in VLM backends.

class marvis.viz.base.VisualizationConfig(figsize: ~typing.Tuple[int, int] = (12, 8), dpi: int = 100, random_state: int = 42, colormap: str = 'tab10', point_size: float = 50.0, alpha: float = 0.7, use_3d: bool = False, viewing_angles: ~typing.List[~typing.Tuple[float, float]] | None = None, zoom_factor: float = 2.0, tight_layout: bool = True, title: str | None = None, xlabel: str | None = None, ylabel: str | None = None, zlabel: str | None = None, show_legend: bool = True, image_format: str = 'RGB', max_image_size: int = 2048, task_type: str = 'classification', use_knn_connections: bool = False, nn_k: int = 5, show_test_points: bool = False, extra_params: ~typing.Dict[str, ~typing.Any] = <factory>)[source]

Configuration for visualization parameters.

__init__(figsize: ~typing.Tuple[int, int] = (12, 8), dpi: int = 100, random_state: int = 42, colormap: str = 'tab10', point_size: float = 50.0, alpha: float = 0.7, use_3d: bool = False, viewing_angles: ~typing.List[~typing.Tuple[float, float]] | None = None, zoom_factor: float = 2.0, tight_layout: bool = True, title: str | None = None, xlabel: str | None = None, ylabel: str | None = None, zlabel: str | None = None, show_legend: bool = True, image_format: str = 'RGB', max_image_size: int = 2048, task_type: str = 'classification', use_knn_connections: bool = False, nn_k: int = 5, show_test_points: bool = False, extra_params: ~typing.Dict[str, ~typing.Any] = <factory>) → None
class marvis.viz.base.VisualizationResult(image: ~PIL.Image.Image, transformed_data: ~numpy.ndarray, description: str, method_name: str, config: ~marvis.viz.base.VisualizationConfig, metadata: ~typing.Dict[str, ~typing.Any] = <factory>, fit_time: float = 0.0, transform_time: float = 0.0, plot_time: float = 0.0, highlighted_indices: ~typing.List[int] | None = None, highlighted_coords: ~numpy.ndarray | None = None, legend_text: str = '', stress: float | None = None, reconstruction_error: float | None = None, explained_variance: float | None = None)[source]

class marvis.viz.base.BaseVisualization(config: VisualizationConfig | None = None)[source]

Abstract base class for all visualization methods.

This class defines the interface that all visualization methods must implement to be compatible with the context composer system.

__init__(config: VisualizationConfig | None = None)[source]

Initialize the visualization method.

Parameters:

config Configuration for the visualization

abstract property method_name: str

Return the name of the visualization method.

abstract property supports_3d: bool

Return whether this method supports 3D visualization.

abstract property supports_regression: bool

Return whether this method supports regression tasks.

abstract property supports_new_data: bool

Return whether this method can transform new data after fitting.

fit_transform(X: ndarray, y: ndarray | None = None, **kwargs) → ndarray[source]

Fit the visualization method and transform the data.

Parameters:

  • X Input data [n_samples, n_features]

  • y Optional target values [n_samples]

  • **kwargs Additional parameters for the method

Returns:

Transformed coordinates [n_samples, n_components]

transform(X: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Transform new data using the fitted method.

Parameters:

X Input data [n_samples, n_features]

Returns:

Transformed coordinates [n_samples, n_components]

generate_plot(transformed_data: ndarray, y: ndarray | None = None, highlight_indices: List[int] | None = None, test_data: ndarray | None = None, highlight_test_indices: List[int] | None = None, **kwargs) → VisualizationResult[source]

Generate a plot from transformed data.

Parameters:

  • transformed_data Transformed coordinates

  • y Optional target values for coloring

  • highlight_indices Indices of points to highlight in training data

  • test_data Optional test data coordinates

  • highlight_test_indices Indices of test points to highlight with red X

  • **kwargs Additional plotting parameters

Returns:

VisualizationResult object

get_description(X: ndarray, y: ndarray | None = None) → str[source]

Get a description of this visualization method for the given data.

Parameters:

  • X Input data

  • y Optional target values

Returns:

Description string

Context Composition

Context Composer - The core system for combining multiple visualizations.

This module provides the main interface for creating complex, multi-visualization contexts that can be consumed by VLM backends for enhanced reasoning.

class marvis.viz.context.composer.CompositionConfig(layout_strategy: LayoutStrategy = LayoutStrategy.SEQUENTIAL, max_visualizations_per_row: int = 2, subplot_spacing: float = 0.3, composition_figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (16, 12), composition_dpi: int = 100, max_composition_size: int = 4096, include_individual_descriptions: bool = True, include_cross_references: bool = True, reasoning_focus: str = 'comparison', parallel_processing: bool = False, cache_transformations: bool = True, optimize_for_vlm: bool = True, vlm_model_type: str = 'general')[source]

Configuration for context composition.

layout_strategy: LayoutStrategy = 'sequential'
max_visualizations_per_row: int = 2
subplot_spacing: float = 0.3
composition_figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (16, 12)
composition_dpi: int = 100
max_composition_size: int = 4096
include_individual_descriptions: bool = True
include_cross_references: bool = True
reasoning_focus: str = 'comparison'
parallel_processing: bool = False
cache_transformations: bool = True
optimize_for_vlm: bool = True
vlm_model_type: str = 'general'
__init__(layout_strategy: LayoutStrategy = LayoutStrategy.SEQUENTIAL, max_visualizations_per_row: int = 2, subplot_spacing: float = 0.3, composition_figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (16, 12), composition_dpi: int = 100, max_composition_size: int = 4096, include_individual_descriptions: bool = True, include_cross_references: bool = True, reasoning_focus: str = 'comparison', parallel_processing: bool = False, cache_transformations: bool = True, optimize_for_vlm: bool = True, vlm_model_type: str = 'general') → None
class marvis.viz.context.composer.ContextComposer(config: CompositionConfig | None = None)[source]

Compose multiple visualizations into a unified context for VLM reasoning.

This class coordinates multiple visualization methods to create rich, multi-perspective views of data that enable more sophisticated reasoning by VLM backends.

__init__(config: CompositionConfig | None = None)[source]

Initialize the context composer.

Parameters:

config Configuration for composition behavior

add_visualization(viz_type: str, config: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, viz_config: VisualizationConfig | None = None) → ContextComposer[source]

Add a visualization method to the composition.

Parameters:

  • viz_type Type of visualization (e.g., tsne, umap, pca)

  • config Configuration parameters for the visualization method

  • viz_config VisualizationConfig object for the visualization

Returns:

Self for method chaining

fit(X_train: ndarray, y_train: ndarray | None = None, X_test: ndarray | None = None) → ContextComposer[source]

Fit all visualization methods on the training data.

Parameters:

  • X_train Training features

  • y_train Training targets (optional)

  • X_test Test features (optional)

Returns:

Self for method chaining

compose_layout(highlight_indices: List[int] | None = None, highlight_test_indices: List[int] | None = None, layout_strategy: LayoutStrategy | None = None, class_names: List[str] | None = None, use_semantic_names: bool = False) → Image[source]

Create a composed layout of all visualizations.

Parameters:

  • highlight_indices Indices of training points to highlight across all visualizations

  • highlight_test_indices Indices of test points to highlight with red X markers

  • layout_strategy Override the default layout strategy

  • class_names Optional semantic class names for consistent styling

  • use_semantic_names Whether to use semantic names in legends

Returns:

Composed image

get_aggregated_metadata() → Dict[str, Any][source]

Get aggregated metadata across all visualizations.

Returns:

Dictionary with aggregated metadata including visible_classes

Generate a comprehensive reasoning prompt for VLM consumption.

Parameters:

  • highlight_indices Indices of points to highlight

  • custom_context Additional context about the data or task

  • task_description Description of the specific task

Returns:

Generated prompt string

reason_over_data(X: ndarray, y: ndarray | None = None, reasoning_chain: List[str] | None = None, highlight_indices: List[int] | None = None) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Perform multi-visualization reasoning over data.

Parameters:

  • X Input features

  • y Optional target values

  • reasoning_chain Ordered list of reasoning steps/questions

  • highlight_indices Points to highlight for analysis

Returns:

Dictionary containing composed image, prompt, and analysis

get_visualization_comparison() → Dict[str, Any][source]

Get a comparison of all visualization methods.

Returns:

Dictionary with comparison metrics and insights

clear_cache()[source]

Clear cached transformation results.

Get the current configuration.

Layout Management

Layout management for multi-visualization compositions.

This module handles the spatial arrangement of multiple visualizations in a single composed image optimized for VLM consumption.

class marvis.viz.context.layouts.LayoutStrategy(*values)[source]

Available layout strategies for visualization composition.

GRID = 'grid'
ADAPTIVE_GRID = 'adaptive_grid'
SEQUENTIAL = 'sequential'
HIERARCHICAL = 'hierarchical'
FOCUS_PLUS_CONTEXT = 'focus_plus_context'
class marvis.viz.context.layouts.LayoutConfig(strategy: LayoutStrategy = LayoutStrategy.GRID, max_per_row: int = 2, spacing: float = 0.1, padding: float = 0.05, title_height: float = 0.08, legend_width: float = 0.15, background_color: Tuple[int, int, int] = (255, 255, 255), border_color: Tuple[int, int, int] = (200, 200, 200), border_width: int = 2)[source]

title_height: float = 0.08
legend_width: float = 0.15
background_color: Tuple[int, int, int] = (255, 255, 255)

class marvis.viz.context.layouts.LayoutManager(composition_config)[source]

Manages the layout and composition of multiple visualizations.

This class is responsible for arranging multiple visualization results into a single, coherent image that can be effectively processed by VLM systems.

__init__(composition_config)[source]

Initialize the layout manager.

Parameters:

composition_config CompositionConfig object

compose_layout(results: List[VisualizationResult], strategy: LayoutStrategy | None = None) → Image[source]

Compose multiple visualization results into a single image.

Parameters:

  • results List of VisualizationResult objects

  • strategy Layout strategy to use (overrides config)

Returns:

Composed PIL Image

Embedding Visualizations

t-SNE visualization wrapper for ContextComposer compatibility.

This provides a minimal BaseVisualization-compatible wrapper around the existing t-SNE functions for use with multi-visualization contexts.

class marvis.viz.embeddings.tsne.TSNEVisualization(config: VisualizationConfig | None = None)[source]

t-SNE visualization wrapper for multi-visualization contexts.

This wraps the existing MARVIS t-SNE functions to be compatible with the BaseVisualization interface while preserving all the specialized functionality of the original implementation.

property method_name: str

Return the name of the visualization method.

property supports_3d: bool

Return whether this method supports 3D visualization.

property supports_regression: bool

Return whether this method supports regression tasks.

property supports_new_data: bool

Return whether this method can transform new data after fitting.

fit_transform(X: ndarray, y: ndarray | None = None, **kwargs) → ndarray[source]

Fit t-SNE and transform data.

Note: For MARVIS compatibility, this is designed to work with combined train+test data since t-SNE needs to fit all data jointly.

generate_plot(transformed_data: ndarray, y: ndarray | None = None, highlight_indices: List[int] | None = None, test_data: ndarray | None = None, highlight_test_indices: List[int] | None = None, class_names: List[str] | None = None, use_semantic_names: bool = False, **kwargs) → VisualizationResult[source]

Generate t-SNE plot using consistent styling.

Parameters:

  • transformed_data Transformed coordinates

  • y Optional target values for coloring

  • highlight_indices Indices of points to highlight in training data

  • test_data Optional test data coordinates

  • highlight_test_indices Indices of test points to highlight with red stars

  • class_names Optional semantic class names

  • use_semantic_names Whether to use semantic class names

  • **kwargs Additional plotting parameters

Returns:

VisualizationResult object

PCA (Principal Component Analysis) visualization implementation.

PCA is a linear dimensionality reduction technique that finds the directions of maximum variance in the data. Its excellent for understanding linear structure and comparing with nonlinear methods.

class marvis.viz.embeddings.pca.PCAVisualization(config: VisualizationConfig | None = None)[source]

PCA visualization implementation.

Principal Component Analysis provides linear dimensionality reduction by finding directions of maximum variance. Useful for understanding linear structure and as a baseline for comparison with nonlinear methods.

property method_name: str

Return the name of the visualization method.

property supports_3d: bool

Return whether this method supports 3D visualization.

property supports_regression: bool

Return whether this method supports regression tasks.

property supports_new_data: bool

Return whether this method can transform new data after fitting.

fit_transform(X: ndarray, y: ndarray | None = None, **kwargs) → ndarray[source]

Fit the PCA method and transform the data with data cleaning.

Parameters:

  • X Input data [n_samples, n_features]

  • y Optional target values [n_samples]

  • **kwargs Additional parameters for the method

Returns:

Transformed coordinates [n_samples, n_components]

transform(X: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Transform new data using fitted PCA with data cleaning.

Parameters:

X New data to transform [n_samples, n_features]

Returns:

Transformed coordinates [n_samples, n_components]

get_component_loadings() → ndarray[source]

Get the component loadings (principal components).

Returns:

Component loadings matrix [n_features, n_components]

get_explained_variance_plot() → VisualizationResult[source]

Create a plot showing explained variance by component.

Returns:

VisualizationResult with explained variance plot

marvis.viz.embeddings.pca.create_pca_visualization(X_train: ndarray, y_train: ndarray, X_test: ndarray, use_3d: bool = False, whiten: bool = False, random_state: int = 42, **kwargs) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Convenience function to create PCA visualization.

Parameters:

  • X_train Training data

  • y_train Training labels

  • X_test Test data

  • use_3d Whether to create 3D projection

  • whiten Whether to whiten the components

  • random_state Random seed

  • **kwargs Additional parameters

Returns:

Dictionary containing projection results and visualization

UMAP (Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection) visualization implementation.

UMAP is excellent for preserving both local and global structure, often providing clearer cluster separation than t-SNE while being more computationally efficient.

class marvis.viz.embeddings.umap.UMAPVisualization(config: VisualizationConfig | None = None)[source]

UMAP visualization implementation.

UMAP (Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection) is a dimensionality reduction technique that preserves both local and global structure of data. It often provides clearer cluster separation than t-SNE.

property method_name: str

Return the name of the visualization method.

property supports_3d: bool

Return whether this method supports 3D visualization.

property supports_regression: bool

Return whether this method supports regression tasks.

property supports_new_data: bool

Return whether this method can transform new data after fitting.

marvis.viz.embeddings.umap.create_umap_visualization(X_train: ndarray, y_train: ndarray, X_test: ndarray, n_neighbors: int = 15, min_dist: float = 0.1, metric: str = 'euclidean', use_3d: bool = False, random_state: int = 42, **kwargs) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Convenience function to create UMAP visualization.

Parameters:

  • X_train Training data

  • y_train Training labels

  • X_test Test data

  • n_neighbors Number of neighbors for UMAP

  • min_dist Minimum distance parameter

  • metric Distance metric to use

  • use_3d Whether to create 3D embedding

  • random_state Random seed

  • **kwargs Additional parameters

Returns:

Dictionary containing embedding results and visualization

sklearn.manifold visualization implementations.

This module provides wrappers for various manifold learning methods from scikit-learn, including LocallyLinearEmbedding, SpectralEmbedding, Isomap, and MDS.

class marvis.viz.embeddings.manifold.LocallyLinearEmbeddingVisualization(config: VisualizationConfig | None = None)[source]

Locally Linear Embedding (LLE) visualization.

LLE attempts to preserve local linear structure by reconstructing each point from its neighbors. Supports standard, modified, Hessian, and LTSA variants.

property method_name: str

Return the name of the visualization method.

property supports_3d: bool

Return whether this method supports 3D visualization.

property supports_regression: bool

Return whether this method supports regression tasks.

property supports_new_data: bool

Return whether this method can transform new data after fitting.

class marvis.viz.embeddings.manifold.SpectralEmbeddingVisualization(config: VisualizationConfig | None = None)[source]

Spectral Embedding visualization.

Spectral embedding uses graph Laplacian eigendecomposition to find a low-dimensional representation that preserves the graph structure.

property method_name: str

Return the name of the visualization method.

property supports_3d: bool

Return whether this method supports 3D visualization.

property supports_regression: bool

Return whether this method supports regression tasks.

property supports_new_data: bool

Return whether this method can transform new data after fitting.

class marvis.viz.embeddings.manifold.IsomapVisualization(config: VisualizationConfig | None = None)[source]

Isomap visualization.

Isomap preserves geodesic distances on the manifold by computing shortest paths on the neighborhood graph.

property method_name: str

Return the name of the visualization method.

property supports_3d: bool

Return whether this method supports 3D visualization.

property supports_regression: bool

Return whether this method supports regression tasks.

property supports_new_data: bool

Return whether this method can transform new data after fitting.

class marvis.viz.embeddings.manifold.MDSVisualization(config: VisualizationConfig | None = None)[source]

Multidimensional Scaling (MDS) visualization.

MDS preserves pairwise distances between points. Supports both metric and non-metric variants.

property method_name: str

Return the name of the visualization method.

property supports_3d: bool

Return whether this method supports 3D visualization.

Create a comparison of multiple manifold learning methods.

  • y_train Training labels

  • X_test Test data (optional)

  • methods List of methods to compare (default: all available)

  • use_3d Whether to use 3D embeddings

  • random_state Random seed

  • **kwargs Additional parameters for methods

Returns:

Dictionary with results for each method

t-SNE Functions

Refactored t-SNE visualization classes to eliminate code duplication.

This module provides a clean class-based architecture to replace the duplicated functions in tsne_functions.py.

class marvis.viz.tsne_functions.TSNEGenerator(perplexity: int = 30, max_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42)[source]

Core t-SNE computation and coordinate generation.

Eliminates duplication of t-SNE fitting logic across all the original functions. Handles embedding combination, perplexity adjustment, and coordinate generation.

__init__(perplexity: int = 30, max_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42)[source]

Initialize t-SNE generator.

Parameters:

  • perplexity t-SNE perplexity parameter

  • max_iter Number of t-SNE iterations

  • random_state Random seed for reproducibility

fit_transform(train_embeddings: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, n_components: int = 2) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]

Generate t-SNE coordinates for train and test data.

Parameters:

  • train_embeddings Training embeddings [n_train, embedding_dim]

  • test_embeddings Test embeddings [n_test, embedding_dim]

  • n_components Number of t-SNE components (2 for 2D, 3 for 3D)

Returns:

t-SNE coordinates for training data [n_train, n_components] test_coords: t-SNE coordinates for test data [n_test, n_components]

Return type:

train_coords

Abstract base class for t-SNE plotting with shared infrastructure.

Eliminates duplication of figure creation, zoom logic, and legend handling across classification and regression plotters.

Initialize base plotter.

Mixin class that adds KNN pie chart functionality to any plotter.

This eliminates the duplication between KNN and non-KNN variants of the plotting functions and provides pie chart visualization.

class marvis.viz.tsne_functions.TSNEVisualizer(task_type: str = 'classification', use_3d: bool = False, use_knn: bool = False, knn_k: int = 5, perplexity: int = 30, max_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), zoom_factor: float = 2.0, cached_color_mapping: Dict | None = None)[source]

Main unified interface for t-SNE visualization.

This single class replaces all 14 functions from the original tsne_functions.py, eliminating massive code duplication while providing all the same functionality.

__init__(task_type: str = 'classification', use_3d: bool = False, use_knn: bool = False, knn_k: int = 5, perplexity: int = 30, max_iter: int = 1000, random_state: int = 42, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (10, 8), zoom_factor: float = 2.0, cached_color_mapping: Dict | None = None)[source]

Initialize unified t-SNE visualizer.

Parameters:

  • task_type classification or regression

  • use_3d Whether to create 3D visualizations

  • use_knn Whether to include KNN connections and analysis

  • knn_k Number of nearest neighbors (if use_knn=True)

  • perplexity t-SNE perplexity parameter

  • max_iter Number of t-SNE iterations

  • random_state Random seed for reproducibility

  • figsize Figure size (width, height)

  • zoom_factor Zoom level for highlighted points

  • cached_color_mapping Optional pre-computed color mapping from resource manager

create_visualization(train_embeddings: ndarray, train_data: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, test_data: ndarray | None = None, highlight_test_idx: int | None = None, semantic_axes_labels: Dict[str, str] | None = None, **kwargs) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, Figure, str, Dict[str, Any]][source]

Create complete t-SNE visualization.

This single method replaces all 14 original functions: - create_tsne_visualization / create_tsne_3d_visualization - create_combined_tsne_plot / create_combined_tsne_3d_plot - create_tsne_plot_with_knn / create_tsne_3d_plot_with_knn - create_regression_tsne_visualization / create_regression_tsne_3d_visualization - create_combined_regression_tsne_plot / create_combined_regression_tsne_3d_plot - create_regression_tsne_plot_with_knn / create_regression_tsne_3d_plot_with_knn - And more

Parameters:

  • train_embeddings Training embeddings [n_train, embedding_dim]

  • train_data Training labels (classification) or targets (regression) [n_train]

  • test_embeddings Test embeddings [n_test, embedding_dim]

  • test_data Test labels/targets [n_test] (optional)

  • highlight_test_idx Index of test point to highlight

  • semantic_axes_labels Optional semantic axes labels

  • **kwargs Additional plotting parameters (class_names, use_semantic_names, colormap, etc.)

Returns:

t-SNE coordinates for training data [n_train, 2 or 3] test_coords: t-SNE coordinates for test data [n_test, 2 or 3] fig: Matplotlib figure legend_text: Legend description metadata: Plot metadata dictionary

Return type:

train_coords

create_simple_visualization(train_embeddings: ndarray, train_data: ndarray, test_embeddings: ndarray, **kwargs) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, Figure][source]

Create simple t-SNE visualization (backward compatibility).

Matches the original simple function signatures that just returned coordinates and figure.

Utilities

Visualization utilities for MARVIS.

This module provides common functionality for saving and processing visualizations across different MARVIS implementations.

marvis.viz.utils.common.managed_figure(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Context manager for matplotlib figures that ensures proper cleanup.

Usage:
with managed_figure(figsize=(10, 8)) as fig:

# Use figure pass

# Figure is automatically closed

marvis.viz.utils.common.managed_subplots(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Context manager for matplotlib subplots that ensures proper cleanup.

Usage:
with managed_subplots(2, 2, figsize=(12, 10)) as (fig, axes):

# Use figure and axes pass

# Figure is automatically closed

marvis.viz.utils.common.ensure_figure_closed(func)[source]

Decorator that ensures any figures created in a function are properly closed. This helps prevent memory leaks from matplotlib figures.

marvis.viz.utils.common.cleanup_matplotlib_figures(warn_threshold: int = 10)[source]

Clean up all current matplotlib figures and warn if many are open.

Parameters:

warn_threshold Number of figures above which to issue a warning

marvis.viz.utils.common.force_matplotlib_cleanup()[source]

Force cleanup of all matplotlib figures and clear internal state. Use this as a last resort when memory issues persist.

marvis.viz.utils.common.plot_to_image(fig: Figure, dpi: int = 100, force_rgb: bool = True, max_size: int | None = None, format: str = 'png', close_fig: bool = True) → Image[source]

Convert matplotlib figure to PIL Image with optional processing.

Parameters:

  • fig Matplotlib figure

  • dpi Resolution for image conversion

  • force_rgb Convert RGBA to RGB if needed

  • max_size Maximum width/height (resizes if larger)

  • format Image format (png, jpg, etc.)

  • close_fig Whether to close the figure after conversion

Returns:

PIL Image object

marvis.viz.utils.common.save_visualization_with_metadata(fig: Figure, save_path: str, metadata: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, dpi: int = 100, force_rgb: bool = True, max_size: int | None = None, close_fig: bool = True) → Dict[str, str | int][source]

Save visualization figure with optional metadata.

Parameters:

  • fig Matplotlib figure to save

  • save_path Path to save the image

  • metadata Optional metadata to save alongside

  • dpi Resolution for saving

  • force_rgb Convert to RGB mode

  • max_size Maximum image size

  • close_fig Whether to close the figure after saving

Returns:

Dictionary with save information (path, size, etc.)
